summary: The document provides an in-depth look into the surveillance operations against the Soviet Embassy from 1955 to 1972, focusing on the role of Ramon Joseph Alvarez Durant under the cryptonym LIEMPTY. It details his recruitment, the operational structure involving various basehouses (LIMITED, LICALLA, LILYRIC) for targeted surveillance, and his responsibilities in processing surveillance photos and managing teams. The narrative also touches on the involvement of other key figures and concludes with the termination of operations, highlighting the legal and personal challenges faced by Alvarez.
key_findings: Ramon Joseph Alvarez Durant was recruited in March 1955 for surveillance operations against the Soviet Embassy.
The surveillance operations were compartmentalized, utilizing different basehouses (LIMITED, LICALLA, LILYRIC) to target specific areas of the Soviet Embassy.
Alvarez was instrumental in processing surveillance photos and overseeing the operational management of surveillance teams.
A notable mention is a photo allegedly capturing Lee Harvey Oswald at the Soviet Embassy, connecting the surveillance operations to the JFK assassination records.
Project LIEMPTY operations ceased between 1968 and 1972, with participants required to sign secrecy agreements upon termination.
